Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Wearable Tutors in the Embodied Mathematics Classroom

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: The role of embodiment (e.g., the use of both fine-grained and gross motor gestures) in mathematics learning for young students is well-established. With the recent success of mobile games, there is more public awareness of augmented reality - a real-time view of a physical, real-world environment that has elements that are augmented by computer-generated sensory input such as sound, video, graphics or GPS data. This project brings together these concepts of augmented reality and embodied learning to develop a new innovation: mobile-phone-based augmented reality math activities. This research project investigates these activities in public elementary-schools, where students solve math related challenges, and are encouraged to find mathematics in the real objects of classrooms, gyms and playgrounds. Students carry a cell phone-based intelligent system (or a SmartWatch) that supports them as needed, giving hints and feedback as they play multiplayer team-based mathematics games that require them to measure, estimate, compute, discern and discard objects in their environments, both in their minds and using their bodies. This project advances scientific knowledge on how people learn with active physical activities, investigating the role of hand and full-body motions, as well as the role of team-based cooperation in the mathematics classrooms of our public schools.<br/><br/>This project involves a new genre of Cyberlearning Technologies called Multi-Modal Embodied Intelligent Learning and Tutoring Environments that supports learning through (1) Intelligent Tutoring Systems (ITS), which can trace students' knowledge and affect in real time, and personalize instruction through moment-by-moment tracking of students' mental states (i.e. knowledge and affective tracing); and, (2) Embodied Cognition and multi-modal interaction (physically acting on the environment in meaningful ways for more solid understanding and encoding of ideas). This project establishes a new genre of learning technologies that blends well with classroom culture, including hands-on manipulatives and educational games, while still retaining the benefits of intelligent tutoring systems, which consist of smart pedagogical decisions based on a moment-to-moment automatic assessment and understanding of the student at various levels. The project includes a series of experimental interventions that investigate the role of fine-grained gestures and gross motor actions during mathematical problem solving. Specifically, the project investigates (1) the impact of these problem-solving activities on cognitive and affective outcomes; (2) the role of personalized feedback and face-to-face social interactions; and, (3) the elements of the embodied activities that are most effective.

POR.DRECONTENT:
INTELLECTUAL MERIT.

This project studied mathematics learning during late elementary and middle school by bringing Learning Technologies outside of the computer screen. It has measured how physically active (embodied) learning impacts student learning outcomes in K-12 math. This work investigated how mobile technologies can enhance education via embodied and collaborative games, within the context of mathematics learning. This CAREER award has mathematics game playing by students and the relationship between playing and learning, supported by the WearableLearning platform (which was created as part of this award also). We are talking about multiplayer math games, like playground games such as Scavenger Hunts, which include a mobile device (smartphone or tabled) carried or worn by each student (player), who generally play in teams of students.

This project has created the infrastructure for supporting these games, both for playing and creating these kinds of game-like math activities. We called this infrastructure the WearableLearning Platform. Accessible from wearablelearning.org, it is a web service system that communicates with each mobile device (e.g. phones), logs the order of events of players, and allows teachers to later debrief students about their interactions.

This project starts new line of research on embodied and collaborative learning technologies, which has ecological validity in math classrooms. It investigates the benefit of children playing these active multiplayer math games on math learning. Research questions regard understanding the benefit of juxtaposing mobile devices, embodied cognition, hands-on learning and game-like elements to traditional learning technologies, and their potential to be math learning tools that improve achievement on math tests.  

Part of this research has involved research studies on how students move and gesture as they learn mathematics. For instance, detailed cognitive task analyses have been carried out, to understand how students use their hands to measure objects, and common misconceptions in physical measurement that arise while measuring objects. We then created ?embodied hints? that use visuals to support students? measurement procedures while attempting to estimate the height of a variety of objects, using an unmarked 12? dowel.

Other research studies have compared WearableLearning games to equivalent activities that resemble more traditional learning technologies that require students to sit down. We have initial data that establishes that different levels of embodiment, physicality and movement in educational math activities and problem-solving may influence mathematics cognition/learning.

We have created a math games library, accessible from wearablelearning.org, with their designated Math Common Core Standards for teachers and students. These games were designed and implemented in WL?s Game Editor, and are deployed with WL?s Game Player, fit a variety of Math Common Core standards and student ages/grade-levels, concretely for CC standards: 3.G, 3.NF, 4.MD, 4.NF, 5.NF, 6.NS, 7.NS., 7.RP, 8.G and 8.EE. These games were created either by researchers and/or by a team of math or STEM teachers. The process of creating games was part of the research of another NSF award on game creation by teachers and students, and is well understood by now. We collected data for each game to understand its impact in real math classrooms: students also took a test before playing their assigned WL game, and again after playing the game.

We have added professional development modules into the Web site, to make them accessible and playable by other teachers and their students in the future. This addresses a dissemination effort to make physically active, embodied math games, accessible to the general public.

 

BROADER IMPACTS.

Children naturally want to move instead of sitting at desks. This WearableLearning technology holds the promise of matching the cognitive and affective needs of highly active students, and those who affectively disconnect from mathematics as they progress school. 

This research has impacted a wide variety of students, despite of COVID. We have worked with hundreds of students in math classrooms as well as students in afterschool programs in school districts with high percent of underrepresented minorities.

This project has also impacted teachers, who have been an integral part of the design process of these math games, as well as piloting and experimenting them. Teachers have designed about half of the games, given feedback about existing games, as well as the feasibility of WearableLeraning in schools.  These teachers have piloted WearableLearning games in their classrooms, and have given important feedback during the design of a Teacher Dashboard prototype that shall provide support and assessments to teachers. 

We have published and communicated the research community about the goals, ideas and current works in progress regarding this research project on embodied games and embodied math learning technologies. In addition, we have created Professional Development materials online, so that teachers and students can learn how to use WearableLearning to play existing educational games from the library, and even to create their own multi-player educational games.
